lessons.title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
masteryOutcomes: Define Artificial Intelligence in practical, non-sci-fi terms
Identify what makes a system ‚Äúintelligent‚Äù in practice
Distinguish AI systems from traditional software

lessons.title: A Short History of AI
masteryOutcomes: Describe how early AI systems were built
Explain why early AI relied on rules and logic
Identify what changed when data became central

lessons.title: Rule-Based AI
masteryOutcomes: Define rule-based (symbolic) AI
Explain how rules are written and applied
Identify strengths and limitations of rule-based systems

lessons.title: Data-Driven AI
masteryOutcomes: Define data-driven (statistical) AI
Explain how data replaces explicit rules
Describe why data-driven systems scale better

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the AI
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: You will be able to distinguish AI systems from traditional software in everyday scenarios.

lessons.title: Symbolic vs Statistical AI
masteryOutcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI
Compare how each approach handles complexity
Identify which approach powers most modern AI systems

lessons.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
masteryOutcomes: Define Narrow AI using real-world examples
Define General AI conceptually and explain why it does not exist today
Correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities

lessons.title: ML, DL, and LLMs
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs
Explain how these approaches relate to statistical AI
Use correct terminology when describing modern systems

lessons.title: AI in the Real World
masteryOutcomes: Identify real-world applications of AI across industries
Describe what type of data these systems rely on
Explain why AI behavior depends on data quality

lessons.title: AI Limits and Responsibility
masteryOutcomes: Identify common limitations of AI systems
Explain why AI systems can fail or behave unexpectedly

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Cafe orders DataFrame
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: You will be able to load a small CSV of cafe orders into Pandas and inspect its basic structure with DataFrames and Series. Output: A Python script that loads a cafe_orders.csv file and prints info(), head(), and basic column summaries.

lessons.title: Python‚Äôs Data Toolbox
masteryOutcomes: Explain Python‚Äôs role in data analysis workflows
Distinguish Python libraries from core Python language features
Identify when to use Pandas versus NumPy

lessons.title: DataFrames and Series
masteryOutcomes: Define DataFrame and Series using tabular data examples
Explain how rows and columns map to DataFrame structure
Navigate and inspect basic DataFrame components

lessons.title: Loading Real Data
masteryOutcomes: Load CSV data into a Pandas DataFrame
Verify that data loaded correctly using inspection methods
Identify basic issues immediately after loading data

lessons.title: Reading Data Carefully
masteryOutcomes: Inspect datasets to understand structure and content
Identify potential data issues by scanning rows and columns
Formulate simple questions about what the data represents

lessons.title: Selecting and Filtering
masteryOutcomes: Select specific columns from a DataFrame intentionally
Filter rows using logical conditions
Explain filtering logic clearly in plain language

lessons.title: Grouping Data
masteryOutcomes: Group data by categorical features using Pandas
Apply basic aggregations such as mean and count
Interpret grouped results in terms of real-world meaning

lessons.title: Derived Columns
masteryOutcomes: Create new columns derived from existing data
Explain why derived columns can make data more useful
Verify correctness of newly created columns

lessons.title: Data Types & ‚ÄúWhat am I analyzing?‚Äù
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish numerical vs categorical variables
Identify whether a question is univariate or relationship-based
Understand that choosing appropriate summary statistics and visualizations is based on data type and get an overview of main techniques according to data type

lessons.title: Distributions - Looking beyond single numbers
masteryOutcomes: Explain what a distribution represents
Interpret basic distribution shape using a histogram or bar chart
Describe why summary statistics alone can be misleading without distribution context

lessons.title: Mean vs Median - Choosing the right ‚Äúaverage‚Äù
masteryOutcomes: Define mean and median with practical examples
Select mean vs median depending on skew and outliers
Explain how outliers can distort the mean and affect interpretation

lessons.title: Variability & Standard Deviation (Intuition)
masteryOutcomes: Explain variability as how spread out values are
Interpret standard deviation at an intuitive level in terms of high vs low spread
Compare two datasets and infer which has more variability

lessons.title: Randomness, Noise & Why patterns can be misleading
masteryOutcomes: Define randomness and noise in real datasets
Recognize when a pattern may be caused by noise rather than signal
Explain why repeated measurements or samples may lead to different results

lessons.title: Bivariate Thinking - Relationships between two variables
masteryOutcomes: Identify when a question requires bivariate analysis
Choose an appropriate visualization such as a scatter plot for numeric-numeric or a box plot for categorical-numeric
Describe what it means for two variables to move together at an intuitive level

lessons.title: Correlation - Pearson vs Spearman (High level)
masteryOutcomes: Define correlation and interpret positive vs negative correlation
Differentiate Pearson correlation from Spearman correlation at a high level
Explain when Spearman may be more appropriate than Pearson

lessons.title: Correlation ‚â† Causation
masteryOutcomes: Explain why correlation does not imply causation
Identify common pitfalls such as confounders and reverse causality conceptually
Propose ways to reduce wrong conclusions, such as checking other variables or using domain reasoning

lessons.title: Multivariate Intuition - When relationships change
masteryOutcomes: Explain why adding a third variable can change an observed relationship
Describe controlling for another variable conceptually
Understand why multivariate thinking connects to feature selection and ML modeling decisions at a high level
